document.docTitle: Five undescribed steroids from Talaromyces stipitatus and their cytotoxic activities against hepatoma cell lines

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Five undescribed steroids from Talaromyces stipitatus and their cytotoxic activities against hepatoma cell lines

mods:name.mods:affiliation: ** & *** & * & Hubei Key Laboratory of Natural Medicinal Chemistry and Resource Evaluation, Tongji Medical College, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan,

paragraph.docTitle:
Five undescribed steroids from
Talaromyces stipitatus
and their cytotoxic activities against hepatoma cell lines

subSection.paragraph:
Xiao-Nian Li b , Changxing Qi a , Junjun Liu a , Chunmei Chen
a, **
, Hucheng Zhu
a, ***
,

Yonghui Zhang
a, *

materialsCitation.municipality: Key Laboratory of Natural Medicinal Chemistry

docAuthorAffiliation.emphasis: Hubei Key Laboratory of Natural Medicinal Chemistry and Resource Evaluation, Tongji Medical College, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan

paragraph.emphasis: State Key Laboratory of Phytochemistry and Plant Resources in West China , Kunming Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Kunming, 650204, People’ s

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Steroids
Cytotoxicity
A B S T R A C T

Five undescribed sterol derivatives, (22 E ,24 R )-7 α -methoxy-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8(14),22-diene-3 β ,15 β -diol, (22 E ,24 R )-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8(14),22-diene-3 β ,7 β ,15 α -triol, (22 E ,24 R )-3 β ,5 α -dihydroxy-14 β ,15 β -epoxyergosta-7,22-diene-6-one, (22 E ,24 R )-6 α -methoxy-7 α ,15 β -dihydroxyergosta-4,8(14),22-triene-3-one, and (25 S )- ergosta-7,24(28)-diene-3 β ,4 α ,6 α ,26 - tetraol were isolated from the extract of
Talaromyces stipitatus
, along with eight known congeners. This is the first example of a class of ergosterols isolated from
T. stipitatus
. Their structures with absolute configurations were elucidated based on NMR spectroscopic data, ECD calculations, and X-ray crystallographic analyses. All these compounds were tested for their effects on three hepatoma cell lines including Hep3B, HepG2, and Huh-7. Moreover, (22 E ,24 R )-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8(14),22-diene-3 β ,7 β ,15 α -triol and (22 E ,24 R )-9 α ,15 α -dihydroxyergosta-4,6,8(14),22-tetraen-3-one were further evaluated for their impacts on cell cycle progression and apoptosis due to their pronounced cytotoxicity, to uncover their underlying mechanisms. Our results suggested that their antiproliferative activities were mainly mediated by inducing cell apoptosis.

Talaromyces stipitatus C.R. Benj.
( Trichocomaceae ) is a potential but underexplored species, closely related to
Penicillium
, which is known to produce polyketides and terpenoids as principal products ( Noinart et al., 2017 ; Zang et al., 2016a). An incredible examplification of remarkable structural complexity and biological diversity in polyketides from
T. stipitatus
is the duclauxin derivatives, which are a series of oxaphenalenone dimers that comprise the 6/6/6/5/6/6/6 ring system ( Bryant et al., 1995 ; Chaudhary et al., 2020 ; Gao et al., 2018 ; Zang et al., 2016b). In our previous report, four fusicoccane diterpenoids with an unparalleled 5/8/6 carbon skeleton were obtained (Zhang et al., 2020), which stimulated us to further explore diverse bioactive compounds from
T. stipitatus
.
* Corresponding author.
** Corresponding author.
*** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: chenchunmei@hust.edu.cn (C. Chen), zhuhucheng@hust.edu.cn (H. Zhu), zhangyh@mails.tjmu.edu.cn (Y. Zhang).
1 These authors contributed equally to this work.

As part of our ongoing investigation, five undescribed ergosterol derivatives ( 1–2 and 4–6 ) along with eight known congeners were identified. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a class of ergosterols isolated from
T. stipitatus
. All of these compounds were evaluated for their antiproliferative activities against Hep3B, HepG2, and Huh-7 hepatoma cell lines. Compounds 4 and 8 showed a remarkable cytotoxicity, cell cycle progression and apoptosis induced by the two compounds and therefore were detected in order to explain the mechanisms of their function. Meanwhile, the selectivity of both compounds on hepatoma suggested their potential as drug candidates against hepatoma.

Compound 1 was obtained as a white powder. Its molecular formula was established as C 29 H 46 O 4 based on the HRESIMS ion peak at m/z 481.3262 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 29 H 46 O 4 Na, 481.3294), requiring a hydrogen deficiency index of seven. The 1 H NMR spectrum showed signals for two olefinic protons [ δ H 5.26 (1H, dd, J = 15.2, 7.3 Hz, H-22) and 5.24 (1H, dd, J = 15.2, 8.1 Hz, H-23)], six methyls [ δ H 1.06 (3H, s, H 3 -18), 1.03 (3H, d, J = 6.7 Hz, H 3 -21), 0.96 (3H, d, J = 7.5 Hz, H 3 -28), 0.95 (3H, s, H 3 -19), 0.87 (3H, d, J = 7.5 Hz, H 3 -26), and 0.86 (3H, d, J = 7.3 Hz, H 3 -27)], and one methoxy group [ δ H 3.47 (3H, s, H-29)]. The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra of 1 displayed 29 carbons, corresponding to four olefinic carbons, three quaternary carbons (one oxygenated), nine methine carbons (four oxygenated), six methylenes, and seven methyl groups (including a methoxy). These typical signals suggested 1 to be an ergostane-type steroid derivative.

The 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC experiments ( Fig. 2 ) revealed that compound 1 possesses a structure similar to (22 E )-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8 (14),22-diene-3 β ,7 α ,15 α -triol ( 3 ). The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra of 1 displayed an additional methoxy ( δ C 55.6, Me-29) as compared with 3 , which along with the HMBC spectrum correlation from Me-29 to C-7 ( δ C 72.4) confirmed the existence of a methoxy at C-7. The relative configuration of 1 was determined based on its NOESY spectrum ( Fig. 3 ) and key coupling constants. Generally, Me-18 of sterols is β -oriented and the NOESY signal of Me-18/H-11a revealed that they were cofacial and should adopt a dipseudoaxial relationship. Moreover, the NOESY correlations of Me-19/H-11a and Me-19/H-7 indicated the β -orientation of Me-19 and H-7, which also suggested the α -orientation of the epoxy ring at C-5 and C-6. In addition, the interactions of Me-19/H-1a and H-3/H- 1b along with the coupling constant of H-3 (tt, J = 11.1, 5.6 Hz) revealed the β -orientation of C-3-OH. The NOESY correlation of C-7-OCH 3 /H-15 disclosed the β -orientation of C-15-OH. The trans stereochemistry of the double bond was then deduced from the coupling constant between H-22 and H-23 ( J = 15.2 Hz). The relative configurations of the remaining chiral centers, including C-21 and C-28, were determined to be identical to these of 3 by comparison of their 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Kikuchi et al., 2019 ). Finally, the structure of 1 with an absolute configuration was determined via X-ray diffraction analysis ( Fig. 5 ). Thus, compound 1 was determined to be (22 E ,24 R )-7 α -methoxy-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8 (14),22-diene-3 β ,15 β -diol.

Compound 2 was isolated as a white powder, which shared the same molecular formula of C 28 H 44 O 4 as that of 3 based on the HRESIMS data. The 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 2 ( Tables 1 and 2 ) closely resembled those of 3 , except for the obviously shifted signals of C-5 (1.9 ppm), C-6 (+ 1.0 ppm), C-7 (1.5 ppm), C-8 (+ 2.6 ppm), and C-14 (2.6 ppm). After detailed analyses of the 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC spectra, 2 and 3 were a pair of stereoisomers possessing the same planar structure. The NOESY interaction of Me-19/C-7-OH ( Fig. 3 ), along with the abovementioned changes in the 13 C NMR data, suggested that 2 is the C-7 epimer of 3 . The structure and absolute configuration of compound 2 was further determined by X-ray diffraction analysis ( Fig. 5 ). Therefore, compound 2 was elucidated as (22 E ,24 R )-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8(14),22- diene-3 β ,7 β ,15 α -triol.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Key 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC correlations of compounds 1 and 4–6 .
Fig. 3. The NOESY correlations of compounds 1 , 2 , and 4–6.

subSection.paragraph: Compound 4 was obtained as a white powder. Its molecular formula, C 28 H 42 O 4 , was determined using the HRESIMS spectrum with a pseudomolecular ion peak at m/z 465.2990 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 28 H 42 O 4 Na, 465.2981), suggesting eight degrees of unsaturation. The IR spectrum indicated the presence of hydroxy ( 3386 cm 1 ) and conjugated carbonyl ( 1676 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H NMR spectrum indicated signals for three olefinic protons [ δ H 5.83 (1H, d, J = 2.8 Hz, H-7), 5.38 (1H, dd, J = 15.3, 8.1 Hz, H-22), and 5.20 (1H, dd, J = 15.3, 8.1 Hz, H-23)], six methyls [ δ H 1.01 (3H, s, H 3 -18), 0.98 (3H, d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -28), 0.95 (3H, d, J = 6.2 Hz, H 3 -21), 0.94 (3H, s, H 3 -19), 0.88 (3H, d, J = 6.8 Hz,H 3 -27), and 0.85 (3H, d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -26)], and two oxygenated methine groups [ δ H 3.94 (1H, tt, J = 11.6, 4.6 Hz, H-3) and 3.22 (1H, m, H-15)]. The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra of 4 revealed 28 carbons, including one conjugated carbonyl, four olefinic carbons, four quaternary carbons, seven methines (two oxygenated), six methylenes, and six methyl groups. These data of compound 4 resembled those of gymnastrone B ( Amagata et al., 1998 ), except for the presence of additional hydroxy groups at C-3 and C-5 and the disappearance of the carbonyl at C-3. Further analyses of the 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC correlations of 4 ( Fig. 2 ) elucidated the planar structure of 4 . The NOESY cross-peak between Me-19 and H-4b revealed that they were cofacial (in a dipseudoaxial relationship), which indirectly proved the α -orientation of C-5-OH. The obvious NOESY correlations of H-3/H-1a and H-1b/Me-19, and the coupling constants of H-3 (tt, J = 11.1, 4.6 Hz) revealed the β -orientation of C-3-OH. The orientation of the epoxy at C-14 and C-15 was assigned as β by a comparison of the NMR data of 4 with that of gymnastrrone B. Thus, the relative configuration of 4 was established. The absolute configuration of 4 was confirmed via X-ray diffraction analysis as shown ( Fig. 5 ). Therefore, 4 was elucidated as (22 E ,24 R )-3 β , 5 α -dihydroxy-14 β ,15 β -epoxyergosta-7,22-diene-6-one.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Experimental ECD curve of 5 and calculated ECD curves of 5 and ent- 5 .

subSection.paragraph:
Compound 5 was isolated as a colorless oil, and its molecular formula was deduced to be C 29 H 44 O 4 based on the HRESIMS ion peak at m/z 479.3138 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 29 H 44 O 4 Na, 479.3137). The 1 H NMR spectrum indicated signals for three olefinic protons [ δ H 6.15 (1H, d, J = 1.9 Hz, H-4), 5.20 (1H, m, H-22), and 5.20 (1H, m, H-23)], six methyls [ δ H 1.11 (3H, s, H 3 -19), 1.04 (3H, d, J = 6.7 Hz, H 3 -21), 0.91 (3H, d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -28), 0.87 (3H, s, H 3 -18), 0.82 (3H, d, J = 6.7 Hz, H 3 -27), and 0.80 (3H, d, J = 6.7 Hz, H 3 -26)], one methoxy group [ δ H 3.48 (1H, s, H-29)], and three oxygenated methine groups [ δ H 4.90 (1H, d, J = 4.1 Hz, H-7), 4.83 (1H, d, J = 4.8 Hz, H-15), and 3.89 (1H, dd, J = 4.1,1.9 Hz, H- 6),]. The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra of 5 displayed 29 carbons, established as one conjugated carbonyl, six olefinic carbons, two quaternary carbons, eight methines (three oxygenated), five methylenes, and seven methyl groups. The 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC data revealed that compound 5 possessed a similar structure as 10 did ( Weng et al., 2010 ), except for the presence of an additional methoxy at C-6 and hydroxyl at C-7. In the HMBC spectrum, correlations from H-4 to C-6 ( δ C 79.0) and from H-7 to C-9 ( δ C 42.8) and C-14 ( δ C 157.1), along with the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-6 ( δ H 3.89)/H-7 ( δ H 4.90), confirmed the existence of the methoxy at C-6 and hydroxyl at C-7. The relative configuration of 5 was determined by its NOESY spectrum and H–H coupling constants. Based on the NOESY correlations of Me-19/H-6, Me-19/H-11, and H-11/Me-18, Me-18, Me-19, and H-6 were assigned to be β -oriented and in the dipseudoaxial relationship. Therefore, the coupling constant of H-6 and H-7 ( J 6,7 = 3.8 Hz) indicated the α -orientation of C-7-OH. In addition, the obvious NOESY correlation of H-20/Me-18 indicated the α -orientation of H-17, and according to the NOESY correlation of H-17/H-15, H-15 and H-17 were in the same orientation. Thus, the relative configuration of 5 was established. Since the theoretical ECD curve of 6 R ,7 S ,9 S , 10 R ,13 R ,15 R ,17 R ,20 R ,24
R -5
matched well with the experimental ECD curve of 5 ( Fig. 4 ), the absolute configuration of 5 was determined as shown. Therefore, 5 was elucidated as (22 E , 24 R )-6 α -methoxy-7 α ,15 β -dihydroxyergosta-4,8(14),22-triene-3-one.

Compound 6 was isolated as colorless needles, and its molecular formula was determined to be C 28 H 46 O 4 based on its HRESIMS ion peak at m/z 469.3277 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 28 H 46 O 4 Na, 469.3294), suggesting six degrees of unsaturation. The 1 H NMR spectrum showed signals for four olefinic protons [ δ H 5.12 (1H, d, J = 2.1 Hz, H-7), 4.77 (1H, brs, H 2 -28), and 4.75 (1H, brs, H-28)], four methyls [ δ H 1.06 (3H, d, J = 7.0 Hz, H 3 -27), 0.99 (3H, d, J = 6.5 Hz, H 3 -21), 0.89 (3H, s, H 3 -19), and 0.59 (3H, s H 3 -18)], one oxygenated methylene group [ δ H 3.58 (1H, dd, J = 10.7, 5.9 Hz, H 2 -26), δ H 3.35 (1H, m, H 2 -26)], and three oxygenated methines [ δ H 4.28 (1H, dd, J = 9.3, 2.1 Hz,H-6), 3.72 (1H, dd, J = 10.2, 8.9 Hz, H-4) and 3.35 (1H, m, H-3)]. The 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra of 6 revealed 28 carbons, corresponding to four olefinic carbons, two quaternary carbons, nine methine carbons (three oxygenated), nine methylene (one oxygenated), and four methyl groups. Careful analyses of the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra revealed that compound 6 is similar to (25 S )-24-methyl-5 α -cholest-24( 241 )-ene- 3 β ,4 β ,6 α ,15 β, 26 - pentol (certonardosterol B) ( Wang et al., 2003 ) except for the absence of a hydroxy at C-15 and the presence of a double bond between C-7 and C-8 ( Fig. 1 ). The relative configuration of the nucleus is consistent with certonardosterol B and the absolute configuration was confirmed via X-ray diffraction analysis. Therefore, 6 was established as (25 S )-ergosta-7,24(28)-diene-3 β ,4 α ,6 α ,26 - tetraol.

tableNote.paragraph: ‑ 6 c Recorded in CDCl. “o” means overlapped.

caption.paragraph: Cytotoxic activities of the isolated compounds against hepatoma cell lines.

subSection.paragraph: Compounds 3 and 7–13 were identified as (22 E )-5 α ,6 α -epoxyergosta-8(14),22-diene-3 β ,7 α ,15 α -triol ( 3 ) ( Kikuchi et al., 2019 ), (22 E , 24 R )-ergosta-3 β ,5 α -dihydroxy-7,22-dien-6-one ( 7 ) ( Deng et al., 2013 ), (22 E ,24 R )-9 α ,15 α -dihydroxyergosta-4,6,8(14),22-tetraen-3-one ( 8 ) ( Shi et al., 2019 ), 15 R , 20 R, 24 R , Δ 4,6,8(14),22 -tetraene-3-one-ergosterol ( 9 ) ( Weng et al., 2010 ), 15 S , 20 R , 24 R , Δ 4,6,8(14),22 -tetraene-3-one-ergosterol ( 10 ) ( Weng et al., 2010 ), (22 E ,24 R )-ergosta-4,6,8(14), 22-tetraen-3,15-dione ( 11 ) ( Wang et al., 2012 ), (22 E ,24 R )-ergosta-5 β , 6 β -epoxy-3 β ,7 α ,9 α -trihydroxy-8(14),22-dien-15-one ( 12 ) ( Wang et al., 2012 ), and (22 E ,24 R )-ergosta-7,22-dien-3,5,6-triol ( 13 ) ( Qiao et al., 2017 ) by the comparison of their NMR data with those reported in the literature.

Compounds 1–13 were tested for their effects on hepatoma cell lines including Hep3B, HepG2, and Huh-7. As a result, compounds 4 , 8 , 9 , 10 , and 11 demonstrated potent inhibition against the tested hepatoma cell lines (Fig. S56). Subsequently, we determined the IC 50 values of these compounds in the three cell lines. As observed in Table 3 , compounds 4 and 8 showed remarkable cytotoxic effects against the Hep3B and HepG2 cell lines with IC 50 values ranging from 4.75 to 8.85 μ M and 5.26–6.29 μ M, respectively. For the Huh-7 cells, there was a slight increase in the IC 50 values of both compounds, 13.78 and 16.23 μ M respectively. Compounds 9 , 10 , and 11 were generally less potently cytotoxic against the cell lines used compared to compounds 4 and 8 .

tableNote.paragraph: a Results are expressed as the mean standard error.

subSection.paragraph: Compounds 4 and 8 demonstrated pronounced cytotoxicity in the hepatoma cell lines, therefore, we further explored to gain insight into the mechanism of their actions. To examine whether compounds 4 and 8 have effects on cell cycle progression, we detected the DNA content using flow cytometry. As shown in Fig. 6 , compound 8 increased the proportion of S phase cells to 47.06 ± 2.06%, compared with 33.08 ± 1.80% of the corresponding controls, at 5 μ M for 24 h on Hep3B cells (p < 0.001), resulting in a significant decrease in the G2 phase (p < 0.01). Our results suggested that the antiproliferative effect of compound 8 was associated with its ability to induce S phase cell cycle arrest. Thus, no significant changes were observed in cells treated with compound 4 .

Since compound 4 exerted a slight impact on cell cycle progression, we presumed that other factors might also participate in its inhibitory effect against the Hep3B cells. In view of this, a flow cytometric analysis was performed to determine the cell apoptosis death induced by compounds 4 and 8 . As observed in Fig. 7 , the proportion of apoptotic cells induced by compound 8 increased from 12.5 ± 0.5% at 24 h to 41.2 ± 1.1% at 48 h and 5 μ M. The latter value was ten times higher than that of the control group (3.9 ± 1.0%, p < 0.0001) considering early and late apoptosis. On the other hand, cells treated with compound 4 at 5 μ M for 48h displayed 41.1 ± 1.3% apoptosis, a value much higher than that of the control (p < 0.0001). Both treatment groups showed no significant difference (p > 0.05) from the positive control sorafenib ( Keating, 2017 ) (44.6 ± 0.9%) at 48 h ( Fig. 7 ).

Given that cells undergoing apoptosis show nuclear fragmentation and chromatin condensation ( Ma et al., 2009 ), we examined the morphological changes in Hep3B cells after treatment with 5 μ M compounds 4 and 8 for 48 h. In keeping with sorafenib, cells treated with compounds 4 or 8 showed typical apoptotic features such as DNA fragmentation, condensed chromatin and apoptotic bodies compared with the solvent control (0.1% DMSO), as depicted in Fig. 8 . These results provided convincing evidence that compounds 4 and 8 induced apoptosis and cell death.

To determine the toxic effects of compounds 4 and 8 against normal cells and thus show their selectivity for hepatoma cells, their IC 50 values against the nontumorous human liver cell line LO2 were also evaluated. Compounds 4 and 8 were 49.3 and 57.1 μ M respectively, which were significantly higher (p < 0.001 and p < 0.001) than those on target hepatoma cell lines. These data indicate that compounds 4 and 8 can selectively trigger cell death in hepatoma cells, suggesting their potential for further consideration as lead compounds.

Talaromyces stipitatus
is a universal species of the genus
Talaromyces
, and previous investigations have indicted the potential of the compounds in terms of their structural diversity and complexity. In our current study, a series of ergosterols were discovered, including five new ergosterols along with eight known compounds. Notably, compounds 4 and 8 displayed a remarkable cytotoxicity against the hepatoma cell lines. The results of the cell cycle progression and apoptosis suggested that their effects were mainly mediated by inducing apoptosis. Our findings have enriched the chemical diversity and bioactivity of sterols.

Optical rotations, ECD, UV, IR spectra and high-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (HRESIMS) were conducted on the instruments we utilized in a previous report. (Zhang et al., 2020). Crystallographic experiments were performed on a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Cu K α radiation ( λ = 1.54178 Å). Semipreparative high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) utilized an Agilent 1260 equipped with a UV detector, using a Welch Ultimate XB-C 18 column (5 μ m, 10 × 250 mm ). Silica gel (Qingdao Marine Chemical Inc., China ), Sephadex LH-20 (GE Healthcare Bio-Sciences AB, Sweden ), and ODS (50 μ m,Merck, Germany ) were utilized in the column chromatography. Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) was performed using silica gel 60 F 254 (Yantai Chemical Industry Research Institute).

The fungus
Talaromyces stipitatus
was isolated from the soil of Beijing , China . An NCBI BLAST analysis of its partial sequence

caption.paragraph: Fig. 6. Cell cycle phases of Hep3B cells. Cells were treated for 24 h with (a) 0.2% DMSO; (b) compound 4 at 5 μ M; (c) compound 8 at 5 μ M; and (d) sorafenib at 3.5 μ M. After labeling with PI staining solution, the cells were subjected to flow cytometry. Diagrams of the cell cycle phases are shown ***p < 0.001 compared with the control group.

Fig. 7. Apoptosis in Hep3B cells induced by compounds 4 and 8 . Cells were treated with (a, e) 0.1% DMSO (control); (b, f) compound 4 at 5 μ M; (c, g) compound 8 at 5 μ M, and (d, h) sorafenib at 3.5 μ M for a period of 24 and 48 h. The four subpopulations indicate Q4, viable; Q3, early apoptotic; Q2, late apoptotic; and Q1, necrotic. Quantification of the percentage of cells in each quadrant is shown. ***p < 0.001, ****p < 0.0001 compared with the control group.

subSection.paragraph:
(BNCC226199) showed that it is 100% identical to
T stipitatus
strain CBS 236.60 (MH857968.1) and
T stipitatus
strain T1D1 (MN518410.1).

The fermentation and extraction of the fungal
Talaromyces stipitatus C.R. Benj.
( Trichocomaceae ) were identical to the procedures described previously (Zhang et al., 2020). Briefly fungi were cultivated on a solid-substrate medium ( 35 kg ) for 32 days at 25 ◦ C. Exhaustive extraction with EtOAc resulted in a crude fraction (250.0 g) which was partitioned by silica gel CC with a gradient elution petroleum ether/- EtOAc (10:1 to EtOAc neat, v/v) to obtain six subfractions (Fr.1–6). Since the steroids were mainly enriched in Fr.2 ( 10.3 g ) and Fr.3 (28.0 g), Fr.2 was further chromatographed on Sephadex LH-20 (MeOH), ODS (50%–100%, v/v) and semipreparative HPLC to afford compounds 4 ( 3.2 mg ), 7 (5.0 mg), 9 ( 3.5 mg ), 10 (3.0 mg), and 13 ( 7.5 mg ). Fr.3 was purified by RP-C18 gel with MeOH/H 2 O (60%–100%, v/v) to give seven fractions (Fr.3A Fr.3G) grounded on the TLC analysis. The Fr.3E was successively separated using silica gel CC with ether/EtOAc (15:1 to 1:1, v/v) and Sephadex LH-20, and then purified by semipreparative HPLC to yield compounds 1 ( 4.1 mg ), 2 ( 5.3 mg ), 3 (7.0 mg), 8 ( 3.3 mg ), and 11 ( 9.5 mg ). Similarly, compounds 5 ( 2.2 mg ), 6 ( 3.9 mg ), and 12 ( 6.1 mg ) were isolated from Fr. 3F.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 8. Nuclear morphology changes in Hep3B cells assessed by fluorescence microscopy using DAPI staining. Cells were incubated for 48 h with (a) 0.2% DMSO; (b) compound 4 at 5 μ M; (c) compound 8 at 5 μ M; and (d) sorafenib at 3.5 μ M. Arrows show apoptotic cells. The results are representative of three different experiments.

The crystallographic data of 1 , 2 , 4 , and 6 were deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (deposition numbers 2024115, 2024114, 2024062, and 2024238, respectively).

The ECD calculation of 5 was implemented using Gaussian 09W. The electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra of each conformer were calculated at the B3LYP/6–311++ G(d,p)/B3LYP/6-31G (d) level, utilizing the TDDFT method with MeOH as the solvent and the IEFPCM solvation model performed in the Gaussian 09 program. The ECD spectra were simulated using a Gaussian function with a bandwidth σ of 0.3 eV. Based on the population contributions of the spectra, Boltzmann weighting was combined and a UV correction was applied.
The 1D and 2D NMR, MS, IR, UV, and X-ray crystallographic data of 1 , 2 , 4 , and 6 are included in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
